page.title: 03Farming around Elkstone.
page.content: The local farms depend largely on wheat and barley, although the steeper slopes in the valleys, which cannot be cultivated, support dairy cattle and some sheep. The monoculture of cereals occurs despite the thin and stoney soils on the Cotswold limestone and depends on artificial fertilisers to maintain soil fertility. Such is the predominance of cereals that the massive fields on the dip slope can create a rather monotonous landscape. Certainly this is the appearance of the area from the Ermin Way. Within the small valleys, however, the landscape is more varied and therefore more attractive. Here there are many patches of woodland, both natural and artificial, the largest of which is Shewel Wood, S.E. of Elkstone.
